title: How to Get Rid of Stream Delay on Twitch: A Step-by-Step Guide

steps.title: Open Twitch in your internet browser.
steps.content: Open Twitch in your internet browser. Type https://www.twitch.tv into the address bar, and press ↵ Enter or ⏎ Return on your keyboard. If you're not automatically signed in, click the Log In button on the top-right corner of the page, and log in to your streamer account.

steps.title: Click your profile picture on the top-right.
steps.content: Click your profile picture on the top-right. You can find a thumbnail of your profile picture in the upper-right corner of the page. It will open a drop-down menu.

steps.title: Click Settings on the drop-down menu.
steps.content: Click Settings on the drop-down menu. This will open your Settings page.

steps.title: Click the Channel and Videos tab.
steps.content: Click the Channel and Videos tab. You can find it below the "Settings" heading at the top. It will open your Channel settings on a new page.

steps.title: Select Low latency next to "Latency mode.
steps.content: Select Low latency next to "Latency mode. " You can find this option at the bottom of the "Stream Key & Preferences" section in your Channel settings. This option automatically reduces stream delay on average by 33. The changes will take effect next time you start a live broadcast. [1] X Research source Your changes are saved automatically.

steps.title: Check the upload speed of your internet.
steps.content: Check the upload speed of your internet. You need a relatively high upload speed in order to broadcast high-quality streams with low delay. You can use https://www.speedtest.net to see your average upload speed. To make sure about your upload speeds, you can also go to https://testmy.net/upload , and select something around 6MB in the Manual Test Size section. This will upload random data that amounts up to the selected file size, and give you your constant upstream numbers, which live streams usually rely on. Usually, 1500kbps (1.5mbps) is the recommended minimum for a decent 720p stream at 30fps , and you need closer to 2mbps or higher for better streams at this quality.

steps.title: Change the encoding and quality options in your streaming software.
steps.content: Change the encoding and quality options in your streaming software. Depending on your internet connection and hardware, you may simply need to lower your encoding and video quality settings to get less stream delay.

steps.title: Check if you have a fixed delay set in your streaming software.
steps.content: Check if you have a fixed delay set in your streaming software. Most streaming software like OBS Studio will allow you to set a constant delay in your stream. Make sure to check your streaming software's settings, and disable any fixed delay option set for your streams. If you're using OBS Studio, you can check out this article to see the detailed instructions on how to set it up for Twitch.

steps.title: Try different streaming software.
steps.content: Try different streaming software. You can check out some of the most popular streaming software like OBS Studio, XSplit, and Bandicam to see which one works the best for your system. You can get: OBS Studio at https://obsproject.com XSplit at https://www.xsplit.com Bandicam at https://www.bandicam.com

steps.title: Disconnect some of your extra hardware like cameras and microphones.
steps.content: Disconnect some of your extra hardware like cameras and microphones. Having multiple pieces of hardware set up and routed through various software may hog your upload rates, and increase your stream latency.

steps.title: Look into changing your internet service provider (ISP).
steps.content: Look into changing your internet service provider (ISP). If your upload speeds are too low for streaming, you may want to look into different ISP options in your area, or different data plans offered by your ISP. Make sure to talk to your ISP's customer representative about online streaming. They may suggest a new data plan that will help increase your upload speeds, and allow higher quality streams with low latency.
